quotes.topic_title: Opening: receiving feedback with gratitude
quotes.text: If you give me feedback, I'll be like, "Hey, thank you so much. This is super helpful," because people are like, "Oh, he actually likes the feedback."
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Models an intentional, repeatable way to respond to feedback that makes others more willing to share it again.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: receiving feedback with gratitude
quotes.text: Now, inside my heart might be melting. I'm like, "Oh, I thought I got better at this." You know what I mean?
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights the gap between internal reaction and external response, normalizing discomfort while still choosing a productive behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: receiving feedback with gratitude
quotes.text: But externally, I'm like, "Hey, thank you," and I mean it. I think that's the key that most people don't focus on.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Emphasizes gratitude as a deliberate practice that changes the feedback dynamic and is often overlooked.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: receiving feedback with gratitude
quotes.text: And if you get more feedback, then you'll just get better at the things.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Connects increasing feedback volume to faster skill improvement, making the case for optimizing for more feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: my goal here is to help you get better at the craft of building and growing products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets a practitioner-focused north star: treat product work as a craft you can deliberately improve.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we focus on what skills matter most in advancing a PM's career, and more importantly, all the ways Jules has found to build those skills.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a skills-first career model paired with concrete skill-building methods, not just theory.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also go deep on mentorship, how to find a mentor, what to look for in a mentor, how to get someone to agree to be a mentor, and a lot more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews a practical mentorship playbook covering discovery, selection criteria, and the ask.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable framing of compliance as a go-to-market gate that can accelerate or stall growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Over 3000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point about automating compliance work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Frames SOC 2 as a go/no-go gate for revenue growth, making compliance a strategic sales lever rather than a checkbox.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable reminder that lacking baseline security proof can disqualify you before negotiations begin.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 3000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point to benchmark automation expectations for SOC 2 efforts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Offers a specific time-to-audit claim that can inform planning and resourcing for compliance timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Notion is an all-in-one team collaboration tool that combines note-taking, document sharing, wikis, project management, and much more into one space that's simple, powerful, and beautifully designed.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Notion)
quotes.context: A clear “single workspace” model practitioners can apply when consolidating tools and team knowledge into one system.

quotes.topic_title: Jules’ career journey: Haiti to YouTube
quotes.text: In the Bay Area I wanted to become a PM, which was really hard to get into.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights the real difficulty of breaking into PM, setting up the practical need for alternative entry paths.

quotes.topic_title: Jules’ career journey: Haiti to YouTube
quotes.text: At first, I joined a startup, series a company, became head of product for them, and then join Slack as the first PM on their growth team.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A concrete career strategy: use an early-stage startup role to build PM credibility and then leverage it into a larger-company PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Jules’ career journey: Haiti to YouTube
quotes.text: When I joined revenue was around 50 million; when I left roughly four years ago was 10x that.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A specific impact metric that demonstrates how growth/product work can be quantified and communicated.

quotes.topic_title: Jules’ career journey: Haiti to YouTube
quotes.text: It's really exciting to take a product from nothing to something.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Captures the core product-building mindset—end-to-end creation—especially notable in a large company context.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management paths
quotes.text: It's really, really hard to get into product and there isn't a really set path to do that.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights the core reality that breaking into PM is non-linear, setting expectations and encouraging flexible strategies.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management paths
quotes.text: What I've seen is the path that we just talked about, join a startup and then from there go into different companies.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Offers a concrete entry route: use a startup role to get real PM experience and credibility for later moves.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management paths
quotes.text: And then the other path that is typical is being at a company and then switching product management, especially if you develop domain expertise and there's a need for a PM.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Provides a second practical pathway: leverage internal mobility by becoming the obvious PM candidate through domain expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management paths
quotes.text: So, that's even more frequent.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive emphasis that internal transfers via domain expertise may be more common than the startup route.

quotes.topic_title: First growth PM at Slack: learning fast
quotes.text: I did not know anything about growth, but I was like, "Hey, this is my way in at such a great company."
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career move: using an unfamiliar role as a strategic entry point into a high-quality company.

quotes.topic_title: First growth PM at Slack: learning fast
quotes.text: And then what I did there was really take a learning mindset and lean on mentors, and we can talk about that to really learn the practice of growth and applied for Slack.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Actionable approach for ramping fast in a new domain: adopt a learning mindset and actively leverage mentors to build the skill.

quotes.topic_title: First growth PM at Slack: learning fast
quotes.text: My experience was I got in, didn't know much about growth, and then through mentorship, in particular, one mentor, Bangaly Kaba, sort of learned how to apply growth frameworks to my work.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete method for skill transfer: mentorship that teaches how to apply growth frameworks directly to day-to-day work.

quotes.topic_title: First growth PM at Slack: learning fast
quotes.text: And then when I did that within six months, I was able to ship changes in the new user experience, especially on mobile. That moved the needle by a lot, like double-digit percentages within your [inaudible 00:08:38]. And we're talking about top line metrics like activation.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Specific example and data point showing how quickly mentorship + frameworks can translate into measurable activation gains.

quotes.topic_title: Nonprofits: CodePath and Black PMs Network
quotes.text: With CodePath specifically, what we do is we train over 5,000 students every year at universities, typically the university with strong underrepresented populations, and we help them find internships and jobs at top tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A concrete, scalable model (training + placement) with a specific impact metric practitioners can emulate for talent pipelines.

quotes.topic_title: Nonprofits: CodePath and Black PMs Network
quotes.text: Both of them are nonprofits that I wasn't actually setting out to build them. It's more like I had the need myself or I wish I had those sort of support when I was earlier in my career. And then I started helping folks and then one thing led to the other, especially my co-founders, and then these became big.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A repeatable “scratch your own itch” approach to building communities/products that start as small acts of help and scale over time.

quotes.topic_title: Nonprofits: CodePath and Black PMs Network
quotes.text: It's amazing that it's hard for underrepresented community to see themselves in podcasts, at conferences, at speakers, that sort of thing. So, it gave that opportunity and it also enables us to realize that you're not alone.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights representation and belonging as practical levers—creating visibility moments (events, speakers) that reduce isolation and strengthen community.

quotes.topic_title: Nonprofits: CodePath and Black PMs Network
quotes.text: And we're joking and we're like, "Hey, I bet we can list all the Black PMs we know." And we had basically roughly 15 between the two of us and we're like, "Hey, let's bring them all together in a room and to have a community." From there, started helping each other and that grew from 15 to now over a thousand.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A vivid origin story showing how a simple, low-cost first step (list people → convene a room) can scale into a 1,000+ member network.

quotes.topic_title: Key PM skills: IQ vs EQ buckets
quotes.text: In terms of skills, I think of it in terms of two buckets. One are IQ skills, intellectual skills, like what sometimes people call hard skills. And then the other things are the EQ skills, oftentimes called soft skills.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Introduces a simple two-bucket framework for prioritizing PM skill development over time.

quotes.topic_title: Key PM skills: IQ vs EQ buckets
quotes.text: What I've seen in my career is that early on, I leaned more into the hard skills, the IQ stuff. That was what was most helpful to me. And then later on, I spent more time getting better at the EQ skills.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Offers a career-stage model for sequencing skill-building: IQ first, EQ later as scope grows.

quotes.topic_title: Key PM skills: IQ vs EQ buckets
quotes.text: The reality with PMs is that within each of these buckets, there's so many skills and then you can feel overwhelmed, so my advice is really just start skill by skill.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for avoiding overwhelm by focusing on one skill at a time.

quotes.topic_title: Key PM skills: IQ vs EQ buckets
quotes.text: The other skill that I'll also call out, which nobody talks about for some reason, is interview skills, because so much of what gives you a chance to become better as a PM is working at a great company.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights an under-discussed leverage point—interviewing—as a key enabler of career growth opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Key PM skills: IQ vs EQ buckets
quotes.text: If you think about my career, getting into Slack changed my trajectory and I was able to do that because I got slightly somewhat good enough at interviewing. I barely got the job and then I was really good at execution and got better at these other things, product sense, strategy, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how “good enough” interviewing can unlock a step-change opportunity, after which execution compounds.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing as a career skill: mock practice
quotes.text: When people tell me, "Hey, I'm going to a interview at this company." First question I ask is, "How many mock interviews have you done?"
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic question that reframes interview prep around reps, not passive studying.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing as a career skill: mock practice
quotes.text: And I would recommend people to do dozens of those mock interviews.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Concrete, high-volume practice guidance that most candidates underinvest in.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing as a career skill: mock practice
quotes.text: By the way, most things you do, people give you some feedback so you can get better at it, but interviewing you never get any feedback.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights a structural reason interview performance stagnates and why mock feedback loops matter.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing as a career skill: mock practice
quotes.text: I graduated from MIT and I think even since internship times in '07, I'd interviewed for roles at Google and I didn't get those roles or Meta or various other companies. It's because I wasn't good at interviewing and I didn't know people at those companies.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A specific personal example showing repeated failure can be about interview skill and network—not pedigree.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing as a career skill: mock practice
quotes.text: Let's say three of us, et cetera, three to five, and then you practice with that group who are going through the process.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A practical method for building a small peer pod to make mock interviewing consistent and less stressful.

quotes.topic_title: Underrepresented candidates: stress, belonging, support
quotes.text: Yeah. You want to basically practice so much that even at your worst, you're good enough.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A practical interview-prep standard: build enough reps that performance remains passable even under peak stress.

quotes.topic_title: Underrepresented candidates: stress, belonging, support
quotes.text: I've always felt like most interviews, I literally did my worst. It's just that it was good enough to pass.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe that reduces perfection pressure by aiming for “good enough” outcomes rather than peak performance.

quotes.topic_title: Underrepresented candidates: stress, belonging, support
quotes.text: You're so stressed out, you don't relate to the person, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights the real-world interview conditions (stress + lack of rapport) that practice should intentionally simulate.

quotes.topic_title: EQ skills: communication, self-awareness, blind spots
quotes.text: But then what happened is as I get promoted, managed people and then start having larger scope, then there's a lot of ambiguity and stress that comes in with that increase in scope. And that's where the EQ stuff shows up a lot, specifically things like communications, because it's no longer my team. It's like cross-functional partners, other teams, executives, so you have to communicate all the time to different people.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Highlights the inflection point where seniority increases ambiguity and makes EQ—especially communication across audiences—the main leverage point.

quotes.topic_title: EQ skills: communication, self-awareness, blind spots
quotes.text: What I've seen is, number one, it's much harder to learn these skills than the IQ stuff. The IQ is very intellectual. Sometimes, you just need a mental model, practice a bit. The EQ, I'm still learning these things.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive comparison that sets expectations: EQ development is slower and more ongoing than learning “IQ” skills.

quotes.topic_title: EQ skills: communication, self-awareness, blind spots
quotes.text: Then the other thing beyond it being hard to learn is that the EQ stuff... What you need to focus on is specific to you, so you learn it.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Actionable framing that EQ improvement requires personalized diagnosis rather than generic best practices.

quotes.topic_title: EQ skills: communication, self-awareness, blind spots
quotes.text: Generally, you need someone to put a mirror in front of you irritably.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Memorable advice that mentorship/coaching is often necessary to surface blind spots you can’t see yourself.

quotes.topic_title: EQ skills: communication, self-awareness, blind spots
quotes.text: But in my head I would hear, "I don't agree with this." And that would be my self-talk. "Oh, this person doesn't agree with this," instead of being present and trying to understand where are they coming from and maybe asking follow-ups like, "Hey, thanks for asking the question. Is your concern more about, I don't know, scalability of this approach or is it more that you don't think it's effective even if it's not scalable?"
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Concrete example of reframing questions from perceived disagreement to curiosity, plus a practical follow-up-question script.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Let's be honest, the issue tracker that you're using today isn't very helpful.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A blunt reframing that prompts teams to question whether their current tooling is actually enabling productivity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Linear is different. It's incredibly fast, beautifully designed, and it comes with powerful workflows that streamline your entire product development process, from issue tracking all the way to managing product roadmaps.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Defines a practical evaluation rubric for product/dev tools: speed, design, and end-to-end workflow coverage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What users love about Linear are the powerful keyboard shortcuts, efficient GitHub integrations, cycles that actually create progress, and built-in project updates that keep everyone in sync.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Lists concrete, adoptable workflow features that reduce coordination overhead and improve execution cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Linear is the default tool of choice among startups and it powers a wide range of large established companies such as Versatile, Retool, and Cash App.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides specific examples of adoption across company stages, useful as social proof and benchmarking.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've talked about all these different skills PM should have. What have you found to be most effective broadly at building these skills in your career?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A career-development prompt that shifts the focus from listing skills to identifying repeatable methods for building them.

quotes.topic_title: How Jules builds skills: outcomes, questions, mentors
quotes.text: What I do specifically is when I'm trying to learn something new, I try to think about what is an outcome that I could drive. And if I drive this outcome, it will be proof that I'm better at this thing.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A results-based learning method: define a measurable outcome as evidence of skill growth.

quotes.topic_title: How Jules builds skills: outcomes, questions, mentors
quotes.text: Then once I have this outcome, I work backwards to figure out how am I going to do that.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A simple but powerful mental model: reverse-engineer learning from the desired outcome.

quotes.topic_title: How Jules builds skills: outcomes, questions, mentors
quotes.text: Then what I do is I read a little bit, not a lot about the topic, just to make sure I'm asking the right question. Then I refine my questions and then I find the best people in the field and I just go talk to them.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: An actionable sequence for accelerating learning: minimal reading → better questions → direct expert conversations.

quotes.topic_title: How Jules builds skills: outcomes, questions, mentors
quotes.text: I keep going and that's how I rinse and repeat, and over time I drive the outcome and I also know I'm getting better at this thing by working with the experts.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A repeatable loop for compounding skill: execute, review results with mentors, iterate on the next problem.

quotes.topic_title: How Jules builds skills: outcomes, questions, mentors
quotes.text: You don't have to figure things out for yourself; there's people out there that know these things and they're happy to help.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterweight to the default “learn alone” instinct: leverage others’ expertise to move faster.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observing great artifacts and process
quotes.text: Then I'm like, "Okay. Well, can you help me understand what are people at this company that was awhile back, where you think have done a great job at strategy or what are examples of artifacts?" Then I get these artifacts and I reverse engineering them.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A concrete method for leveling up strategy by collecting strong internal examples and working backward to understand what makes them effective.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observing great artifacts and process
quotes.text: And you start seeing the patterns like, "This person did it in a memo, this person did it in a deck." So, it's not about the format, but what is it about?
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A memorable reminder to focus on underlying thinking and questions answered rather than copying surface-level templates or formats.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observing great artifacts and process
quotes.text: For execution, it would be things like me attending another PMs meeting. "Oh, I heard this person is amazing at executing. Let me just see how they're on a meeting."
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Actionable advice to improve execution by directly observing high-performing peers in real working sessions.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observing great artifacts and process
quotes.text: The other thing, too, is even if you see the greatness around you, some people don't try to break it down, to understand: "Why is this one great and not that one?"
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A practical learning model: deliberate analysis of what differentiates great artifacts from average ones instead of relying on passive osmosis.

quotes.topic_title: Learning by observing great artifacts and process
quotes.text: And then the other thing I'll say, too, is a lot of learning happens through the iterations and not by seeing the final product.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive insight that the most valuable learning comes from watching drafts, feedback, and revisions—not polished end results.

quotes.topic_title: Building EQ: feedback loops, coaching, one skill focus
quotes.text: Also, by the way, I always ask for feedback more than I think many people and I try to see patterns in feedback.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A practical method for EQ growth: solicit lots of feedback and analyze it for recurring themes you can act on.

quotes.topic_title: Building EQ: feedback loops, coaching, one skill focus
quotes.text: It's better sometimes to be wrong but clear than the other way around.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive communication principle that prioritizes clarity over hedging or ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: Building EQ: feedback loops, coaching, one skill focus
quotes.text: And a lot of it is like lifting weights or building muscles; you have to do it every day or every week. And then if you stop doing it, over time you atrophy again.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for EQ as a maintenance-based skill that requires consistent practice to retain gains.

quotes.topic_title: Building EQ: feedback loops, coaching, one skill focus
quotes.text: My approach is typically I'll say, "I'm giving myself, I don't know, three months, six months." It depends on what [inaudible 00:43:00] I want to see in my behavior for these things and then I just go all in on that skill.
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for skill-building: timebox a single skill and focus intensely until behavior changes.

quotes.topic_title: Building EQ: feedback loops, coaching, one skill focus
quotes.text: Sometime it's basically ask in a very specific way, "Hey, I did this presentation. I'm working on, I don't know, having more executive presence. Did you feel that? To which extent did you feel that I showed executive presence?" So, it's a very specific thing versus, "Hey, how did it go?"
quotes.speaker: Jules Walter
quotes.context: Tactical advice for getting higher-quality feedback by asking targeted, low-ambiguity questions instead of generic ones.
